questions.question_text:
Psycholinguists conducted a meta-analysis on whether bilingualism confers an advantage on executive function tasks. They hypothesized that the advantage is stronger for inhibition-heavy tasks and that it increases with age. Effect sizes $d$ (positive values favor bilinguals) are summarized below.

| Age Group                 | Inhibition Tasks (d) | Switching Tasks (d) |
|---------------------------|----------------------|---------------------|
| Children (6–12)           | 0.05                 | 0.10                |
| Young Adults (18–35)      | 0.08                 | 0.14                |
| Midlife (36–55)           | 0.12                 | 0.13                |
| Older Adults (56+)        | 0.28                 | 0.15                |

Which choice best describes data from the table that most directly support the researchers' hypothesis?

A city introduced a weekday morning congestion charge (7:00–10:00) in its central zone. After the policy, average bus speeds within the zone rose by 9% during the charged hours, and car entries fell by 14%. However, the city also implemented signal retiming and opened several bus lanes during the same year. Officials claim that the charge—by directly reducing car entries—caused most of the bus-speed increase, rather than the other changes. Which finding, if true, would most directly support the officials' claim?

Agronomists tested four wheat genotypes under three irrigation regimes to assess yield stability. They argue that DR-7 shows relatively stable yields across water availability, whereas conventional lines are more sensitive to water deficit.

Yields (in $t/ha$):

| Genotype | High Irrigation | Moderate Irrigation | Low Irrigation |
|----------|------------------|---------------------|----------------|
| DR-7     | 5.4              | 5.1                 | 4.8            |
| DR-3     | 5.8              | 4.6                 | 3.3            |
| Conv-1   | 6.0              | 4.9                 | 3.8            |
| Conv-4   | 5.2              | 4.0                 | 2.9            |

Which choice best describes data from the table that support the agronomists' argument?

options.label: The average effect across all ages is larger for switching tasks than for inhibition tasks.
Among children, switching advantage exceeds inhibition advantage by $0.05$, indicating task specificity at early ages.
Inhibition advantage increases monotonically with age, reaching the largest value in older adults ($0.28$), while switching advantages remain relatively stable across ages.
Both tasks show their highest effects in young adults, counter to the hypothesis.

On days when toll readers malfunctioned at several cordon points (briefly suspending charges within the 7:00–10:00 window), car entries into the zone spiked and bus speeds on the affected routes simultaneously dropped, with no changes in weather, incidents, or signal timing.
A neighboring city without congestion pricing recorded a 5% increase in bus speeds over the same year.
Surveys indicated that 60% of former drivers cited rising fuel prices as their primary reason for switching to transit.
Most newly added bus lanes were located outside the charged zone and were introduced gradually over the year.
Under high irrigation, Conv-1 achieves the highest yield (6.0 $t/ha$), indicating that conventional varieties outperform drought-resistant lines when water is plentiful.
DR-3's yield drops by $\frac{5.8-3.3}{5.8} \approx 43%$ from high to low irrigation, showing drought sensitivity in at least one drought-resistant line.
The overall average yield across all genotypes under moderate irrigation is approximately 4.6 $t/ha$.

DR-7's yield declines modestly from 5.4 to 4.8 $t/ha$ (range 0.6 $t/ha$) across high to low irrigation, compared with much larger drops of 2.2–2.3 $t/ha$ in the conventional lines, indicating greater stability for DR-7.
